title: A portfolio does not need polish to be honest
blurb: Polish is not required for work to be meaningful or instructive.
fact: I believe a portfolio can be valuable without polished outputs if it accurately reflects real-world constraints, experimentation, and learning.

title: Polish is deprioritized during exploration
blurb: Time is spent learning and testing ideas rather than refining presentation.
fact: In practice, I intentionally deprioritize polish while exploring ideas so effort goes toward understanding systems and constraints instead of presentation.

title: AI is used as a challenging collaborator
blurb: AI is engaged continuously, even when it disagrees or produces friction.
fact: I work with AI tools in an ongoing, sometimes adversarial way to test whether collaboration under imperfect conditions can still produce functional results.

title: Restraint is a deliberate engineering choice
blurb: Good engineering includes knowing when not to act.
fact: I believe strong engineering judgment includes recognizing when not to intervene, especially when additional complexity does not meaningfully improve outcomes.

title: Proven patterns are preferred over reinvention
blurb: Existing solutions are favored unless there is a clear reason not to use them.
fact: In practice, I prefer proven patterns and existing solutions over reinvention unless there is a clear signal that a custom approach is justified.

title: Work is public to reduce duplicated effort
blurb: Shared abstractions prevent others from rebuilding the same solutions.
fact: Although these tools are built to simplify my own work, they are public because the same abstractions tend to repeat across environments, and sharing them avoids duplication.

title: Abstractions are shared across environments
blurb: The work is applicable beyond a single setup or organization.
fact: The tools are public because the abstractions they encode tend to repeat across different environments rather than being specific to one context.

title: Public does not imply required adoption
blurb: Others are free to reuse or ignore the work.
fact: Making the work public is intended to leave room for others to reuse the tools if helpful, or ignore them entirely if not.

title: System Notes and Hermes best reflect day-to-day work
blurb: These projects most closely mirror how work is actually done.
fact: System Notes, along with Hermes Agent, best represents how I work day to day because the real work happens up front through deliberate design, analysis, and decision-making.

title: Design and reasoning precede implementation
blurb: Most effort is spent before any code is written.
fact: My workflow emphasizes thinking through design, identifying edge cases, mapping patterns, and making deliberate build-versus-delegate decisions before implementation begins.

title: AI systems are built alongside the project
blurb: The AI workflow is designed, not assumed.
fact: The work is not prompt-and-go; it involves building the AI system alongside the project, with decisions about what the AI should implement made deliberately as part of the design process.

title: Rigor follows once core design is clear
blurb: Validation and guardrails are added after foundational decisions.
fact: Validation, guardrails, testing, and other rigor are added after the core design is established rather than being imposed prematurely.

title: Underfoot revealed real-world constraints after shipping
blurb: The most meaningful lessons emerged once the system was live.
fact: Underfoot taught me the most after it shipped, particularly around constraint, cost control, and the realities introduced by running the system in practice rather than in theory.

title: Autonomous and parallel AI coding exposed tooling limits
blurb: Parallel AI work does not yet produce cohesive systems.
fact: The project highlighted how autonomous and parallel AI-assisted coding still falls short of producing cohesive, fully integrated systems with current tooling.

title: Leaving systems intentionally piecewise is sometimes correct
blurb: Incomplete integration can be a deliberate decision.
fact: As a result of these limitations, Underfoot was left intentionally piecewise until the gap between autonomous AI output and cohesive system integration can be meaningfully addressed.

title: Time investment is weighed against perceived perfection
blurb: Refinement is evaluated against diminishing returns.
fact: A recurring tradeoff across my projects is deciding how much time to invest refining details versus accepting that nothing is ever truly finished.

title: Additional effort is evaluated for meaningful value
blurb: Not all refinement justifies its cost.
fact: I regularly evaluate whether additional effort meaningfully improves a project or simply satisfies personal standards that may not add real value.

title: Unfinished does not imply incorrect
blurb: Completion is contextual, not absolute.
fact: I am comfortable knowing that projects may remain unfinished if further refinement no longer justifies the time required.

title: UI refinements were intentionally capped early
blurb: Low-impact polish was deprioritized to protect time.
fact: I consciously stopped adding UI refinements early after learning from a previous hackathon how easily time can disappear into low-impact polish.

title: Time and skill constraints shaped feature decisions
blurb: Scope was adjusted based on realistic limits.
fact: Knowing I was starting late, working within a single weekend, and operating outside my primary skill set, I focused on delivering core functionality instead of over-optimizing the interface.

title: Lower rigor and AI-delegated commits were accepted
blurb: Process rigor was adjusted to match project stakes.
fact: I accepted lower review rigor and delegated commits to the AI because the project stakes were intentionally low and the work was exploratory.

title: The project was treated as iterative documentation
blurb: Learning and capture took precedence over production readiness.
fact: Rather than treating the work as a production-grade deliverable, I approached it as iterative documentation intended to capture decisions and lessons under intentionally low stakes.

title: Projects were created in public from the start
blurb: There was no private-to-public transition.
fact: None of these projects originated as private tools that later went public; they were created in public from the beginning rather than evolving out of private work.

title: Earlier work lived on internal systems
blurb: Public repositories did not reflect prior experience.
fact: For over a decade, my GitHub was largely unused because my professional work lived on internal systems rather than in public repositories.

title: Public building coincided with AI experimentation
blurb: Public repos reduced friction and enabled better tooling.
fact: My return to building coincided directly with experimenting publicly with AI, in part because public repositories reduce friction and provide access to better tooling.

title: UI avoidance required an external forcing function
blurb: A deadline was needed to unblock frontend work.
fact: System Notes is a portfolio website I had been procrastinating building because I do not do UI work, and it only moved forward once a hackathon imposed an external deadline that forced the decision.

title: Shipping under a real timeline was prioritized
blurb: Completion mattered more than personal readiness.
fact: The primary goal was to ship a real site under an external timeline instead of waiting for a subjective sense of readiness to do frontend work.

title: Existence was the success condition
blurb: The outcome was a deployed system, not refined UI.
fact: The successful outcome of the project was that the website exists and is deployed, rather than achieving a high level of frontend polish.

title: AI was paired due to challenge alignment, not preference
blurb: Tooling choices were shaped by external context.
fact: AI was included in System Notes because the next challenge focus made pairing them worthwhile, even though frontend work itself was never an area of personal interest.

title: Delegate Action exists to bridge missing GitHub functionality
blurb: The project fills a specific platform gap.
fact: Delegate Action was built as a temporary GitHub Action to stand in for missing GitHub functionality, specifically the inability to call a coding agent from within an existing GitHub Actions workflow.

title: The workflow logic existed before the action
blurb: The action is an implementation detail, not the core idea.
fact: The workflow logic was already designed, and Delegate Action exists only to invoke that logic in a narrow, controlled way rather than to introduce new behavior.

title: AI is used narrowly for documentation updates
blurb: Agent use is constrained and prompt-driven.
fact: Delegate Action is currently focused on updating documentation per pull request using prompts defined in Awesome GitHub Copilot rather than broad or autonomous code changes.

title: The project is intentionally disposable
blurb: Its lifespan is expected to be limited.
fact: The project is still in testing and intentionally scoped as disposable, with the expectation that GitHub will eventually support this capability natively and eliminate the need for custom glue.

title: Hermantic Agent is a local experimentation playground
blurb: The project is designed for hands-on agent experimentation.
fact: My Hermantic Agent is a custom local playground built on my own machine for experimenting with ADK and personal agent design rather than a hosted or production system.

title: The agent is designed to learn personal workflows
blurb: Adaptation replaces generic prompting.
fact: The intended design focuses on allowing the agent to learn and memorize my specific workflows over time instead of relying on generic prompts or stateless interactions.

title: Stateful interaction is preferred over stateless prompts
blurb: Memory is treated as a first-class capability.
fact: The project is intentionally designed around stateful learning and memory rather than repeated prompt-based interactions.

title: The project is currently design-only
blurb: Implementation has not yet begun.
fact: Hermantic Agent is still in the design phase and has not yet been implemented, with effort focused on defining intent and architecture.

title: The agent is intended to be locally grounded
blurb: Control and context remain on the developer’s machine.
fact: The intended outcome is a locally grounded agent that adapts to how I actually work, rather than relying on external or abstracted execution environments.

title: AI involvement in code must be explicitly disclosed
blurb: Authorship transparency is treated as a requirement.
fact: RAI Lint was built to enforce explicit attribution of AI involvement in code authorship rather than allowing it to remain implicit or invisible.

title: Invisible AI contributions create an accountability gap
blurb: Version history alone is insufficient.
fact: The project directly addresses the accountability gap created when AI contributions are not visible or recorded in version history.

title: Disclosure is enforced through commit linting
blurb: Attribution is operationalized, not advisory.
fact: RAI Lint enforces disclosure by integrating with commitlint and gitlint rather than relying on developer memory or informal convention.

title: AI attribution was successfully normalized
blurb: Disclosure became part of the default workflow.
fact: The outcome of RAI Lint successfully normalized AI contribution disclosure for commits using commitlint and gitlint.

title: Local context was prioritized over generic recommendations
blurb: The planner emphasizes constraints and tradeoffs.
fact: Underfoot is an AI-assisted travel planner designed to surface local context, constraints, and tradeoffs rather than providing generic recommendations.

title: The project originated as a hackathon build
blurb: Initial scope and momentum were time-bound.
fact: Underfoot started as a hackathon project, with early progress shaped by the constraints and tooling available during that event.

title: Extending past intended scope caused over-design
blurb: Lack of boundaries led to complexity.
fact: After the hackathon, I continued extending Underfoot past its intended scope, over-designed the system, and learned firsthand why projects require explicit timeboxing and versioning.

title: Tooling expiration forced a rebuild
blurb: External limits triggered a reset.
fact: When the hackathon tooling free trials expired, the project was repurposed into a separate AI orchestration experiment rebuilt from the ground up using free tools.

title: The project remains experimental and unfinished
blurb: Stability is pending further work.
fact: Underfoot remains in an experimental state, pending testing and fixes following its rebuild and repurposing.

title: Awesome Copilot is a personal pattern library
blurb: The collection reflects an actively used workflow.
fact: Awesome GitHub Copilot is a personal collection of prompts, agents, instructions, and skills that I actively use in my own workflow rather than a curated showcase.

title: Only proven patterns are packaged for reuse
blurb: Sharing follows demonstrated usefulness.
fact: The project was built because these patterns already worked well for me, and packaging them made reuse and consistency easier across projects.

title: The collection enforces consistency across projects
blurb: Shared tooling reduces drift.
fact: Organizing prompts, agents, and skills into a single reference made it easier to apply the same patterns consistently across different projects.

title: The project is a living reference
blurb: The content evolves with ongoing use.
fact: The outcome of the project is a living reference that I actively use as-is rather than a finished or static artifact.

title: AI systems could not see existing Dev.to content
blurb: The problem was discoverability by AI, not humans.
fact: DevTO Mirror was built after discovering that AI systems could not see or reference blog content I had published on Dev.to.

title: The canonical publishing source was intentionally preserved
blurb: The solution avoids relocating original content.
fact: The project was designed to keep Dev.to as the canonical source rather than self-hosting or moving the original writing elsewhere.

title: The project functions as a mirror, not a migration
blurb: Distribution is separated from authorship.
fact: DevTO Mirror exists strictly as a publishing mirror to make content visible to AI tools like ChatGPT and Gemini without changing where or how I publish.

title: A lightweight layer solved AI visibility
blurb: The solution added reach without operational overhead.
fact: The outcome is a lightweight distribution layer that improves AI visibility without altering the publishing workflow or hosting model.

title: Lint decisions are encoded once, not renegotiated
blurb: Consistency is favored over per-project debate.
fact: ESLint Config Echo is an opinionated shared configuration designed to encode linting decisions once instead of renegotiating them across individual projects.

title: The configuration exists to reduce bikeshedding
blurb: Time is protected by removing low-value debate.
fact: The project was built specifically to reduce bikeshedding and inconsistency across repositories by centralizing linting rules.

title: Lint behavior was stabilized across projects
blurb: Rules became predictable and repeatable.
fact: The outcome of ESLint Config Echo was stabilized lint behavior across repositories that adopted the shared configuration.

title: The project was an early AI collaboration experiment
blurb: It predated later tooling and frameworks.
fact: Checkmark Copilot Chat was an early AI experiment built before MCP and before the Awesome GitHub Copilot repository existed.

title: The goal was to share prompts through Copilot Chat
blurb: Invocation was meant to be simple and social.
fact: The project was intended as a simple way to share the prompts and instructions I was using at work so others could invoke them directly from Copilot Chat.

title: Lack of context persistence made the approach unworkable
blurb: The tooling could not support the intended workflow.
fact: Limited documentation and GitHub’s inability at the time to persist context across turns made the approach unworkable without the deeper system already present in VS Code.

title: Choosing not to build a full plugin was deliberate
blurb: Effort was withheld when the cost outweighed the value.
fact: Rather than investing in writing a full plugin to compensate for these limitations, I chose not to pursue the approach further.

title: AI leverage is capped to avoid unnecessary complexity
blurb: The system intentionally stops short of maximal capability.
fact: In this implementation, the AI is intentionally simple and does not attempt to do everything it could, because beyond a certain point complexity outweighs leverage.

title: AI replaces search and navigation with direct answers
blurb: Leverage comes from reducing cognitive overhead.
fact: Where AI adds leverage is in eliminating the need to search, navigate, or infer intent, providing direct answers instead of forcing users to hunt through pages.

title: The same data serves different audiences
blurb: Tone adjusts without mutating the system.
fact: The same underlying data supports judges and recruiters equally, with only minor instruction-level tone adjustments rather than changes to the data itself.

title: System boundaries are enforced deliberately
blurb: Not every possible AI capability is desirable.
fact: The implementation reflects a deliberate boundary where AI stops adding value and begins adding complexity, and that boundary is actively enforced.

title: The AI is explicitly not the author
blurb: Identity separation is enforced.
fact: A core guardrail is that the AI is explicitly not me and must not present itself as the author or decision-maker.

title: The AI is not allowed to guess or infer
blurb: Speculation is treated as an error.
fact: The AI is explicitly not allowed to guess, infer intent, or speculate beyond what is stated in the canonical data.

title: Unstated information is treated as nonexistent
blurb: The system operates under a closed-world model.
fact: If something is not stated in the canonical data, it is treated as not existing rather than being filled in or approximated.

title: Unknowns are escalated back to the human
blurb: The system defers rather than fabricates.
fact: When information is missing, the user is directed to ask me directly instead of the AI attempting to fill in the gap.

title: The system is tested with known-unknown questions
blurb: Accuracy is validated through deliberate probing.
fact: I actively test the system with questions I know I never answered, questions about itself, and questions about specific projects to verify how it behaves under uncertainty.

title: Accuracy is the primary success criterion
blurb: Correct refusal is better than fabricated answers.
fact: As long as the system responds accurately without fabricating information when data is missing, it is considered helpful.

title: The system is tested on questions about itself
blurb: Self-knowledge boundaries are intentionally probed.
fact: Questions about the system itself are used to evaluate whether the AI respects its guardrails and avoids inventing internal state or intent.

title: AI is treated as baseline infrastructure
blurb: Usefulness is measured against modern expectations.
fact: AI is no longer treated as a novelty or gimmick, but as an expected baseline for functional systems, and this implementation is evaluated against that standard.

title: The portfolio is a system-first experiment
blurb: Systems take precedence over finished artifacts.
fact: This portfolio is intentionally designed as a system-first experiment rather than a showcase of finished applications.

title: The portfolio was built under hackathon-style constraints
blurb: Time and scope limits shaped the outcome.
fact: The portfolio was built under hackathon-style constraints and is intentionally exploratory rather than optimized for completeness or polish.

title: Polish and completeness were deprioritized by design
blurb: Exploration was favored over refinement.
fact: The goal of the portfolio was to test how far real-world AI collaboration could be pushed when polish and completeness were explicitly deprioritized.

title: The site itself is the portfolio artifact
blurb: The system replaces a static placeholder.
fact: The site exists as the portfolio artifact itself, replacing a static placeholder and primarily serving to host and expose the underlying system decisions.

title: Perfectionism is active, not paralyzing
blurb: Work pauses rather than being abandoned.
fact: The author is an active perfectionist, meaning work is not left alone permanently but paused until attention shifts and returns later.

title: Directional correctness matters more than completion
blurb: Progress is evaluated by trajectory.
fact: Satisfaction comes from knowing the work is directionally correct rather than fully complete.

title: Iteration is assumed over time
blurb: Revisiting work is part of the system.
fact: The system is designed with the expectation that work will be revisited and iterated on over time rather than finalized in a single pass.

title: Raised in rural Appalachia
blurb: Early life was shaped by geographic isolation.
fact: I was raised in a small coal-mining town in southwest Virginia, deep in Appalachia.

title: Isolation shaped how I understand systems
blurb: Distance influenced perception of access and structure.
fact: Growing up isolated shaped how I see systems, scale, and access.

title: Limited access defined early experience
blurb: Infrastructure was distant and sparse.
fact: The nearest Walmart was a 45-minute drive, and for a long time the biggest city I knew was Bristol.

title: Moved to Georgia as a teenager
blurb: Geographic context shifted in adolescence.
fact: At seventeen, I moved to Georgia, where I have lived ever since.

title: The mountains remain home
blurb: Sense of place persists despite relocation.
fact: No matter where I land, the mountains still feel like home, and Appalachia is the place I keep reaching for.

title: Entered engineering through a nonlinear path
blurb: Career direction was not immediate.
fact: I came to software engineering during my second attempt at college rather than through a direct or early pipeline.

title: Career choice was driven by pragmatism
blurb: Earning potential influenced direction.
fact: A career aptitude test led me to rank options by earning potential, with software engineering at the top.

title: Pragmatism turned into long-term commitment
blurb: Interest deepened after entry.
fact: What began as a pragmatic decision quickly turned into a long-term obsession with the work.

title: Systems thinking outweighs feature building
blurb: Coherence matters more than surface output.
fact: I don’t just build applications; I build systems and push back when things lack coherence.

title: Assumptions are challenged instinctively
blurb: Default practices are questioned.
fact: I debate assumptions instinctively and fix problems before they calcify into standard practice.

title: Large-scale changes are intentional
blurb: Broad modifications are planned, not accidental.
fact: If every file in a repository changes once, it is intentional, and automation follows afterward.

title: Guardrails are required for system stability
blurb: Tooling enforces predictability.
fact: I believe linters, formatters, and guardrails are necessary to keep systems stable and predictable.

title: Manual coding is no longer the primary activity
blurb: Work has shifted to system orchestration.
fact: These days, I write very little code by hand.

title: AI is trained to write code the way I would
blurb: Behavior is constrained by prior standards.
fact: I build AI-augmented systems that write code the way I used to write it myself.

title: Review happens at the system level
blurb: Correctness is evaluated holistically.
fact: My review process focuses on whether systems work, are deterministic, tested, repeatable, and constrained over time.

title: AI is taught, not merely used
blurb: Workflows are designed, not improvised.
fact: I approach AI by teaching it through intentionally designed workflows rather than simply using it as a tool.

title: The goal is durable, constrained systems
blurb: Longevity matters more than novelty.
fact: My goal is to build reusable, durable, intentionally constrained systems that continue to function well long after the initial build.

title: I Build Things is my theme song
blurb: The song represents a personal constant.
fact: I have called the song "I Build Things" my theme song since the first time I heard it.

title: Appalachian ingenuity shaped how I approach building
blurb: Fixing and reusing were learned early.
fact: Growing up with Appalachian ingenuity taught me to fix what breaks, reuse what still works, and take things apart to understand how they function.

title: I dismantled systems before I had the language for them
blurb: Systems intuition predates formal vocabulary.
fact: I have been dismantling systems and sometimes putting them back together since before I had the vocabulary to call them systems.

title: Building is genuinely enjoyable
blurb: Motivation is intrinsic, not symbolic.
fact: Part of why the song resonates is that it is fun, catchy, energetic, and makes me want to build things.

title: Symbolism is chosen for usefulness, not abstraction
blurb: Meaning must still be practical.
fact: I do not treat a theme song as a metaphor exercise alone and chose it because it is motivating, memorable, and genuinely enjoyable.

title: I design systems by hunting failure points
blurb: Failure is assumed, not ignored.
fact: I design systems by actively hunting for failure points, assuming that if something can break, it eventually will.

title: Failures should be found before deployment
blurb: Production is not the test environment.
fact: I strongly prefer finding, understanding, and addressing failures before production rather than shipping something marked "done" and immediately needing a hotfix.

title: Shipping clean matters more than shipping fast
blurb: Stability is the success condition.
fact: If I deploy something, I believe the failure should already have been found, understood, and addressed.

title: Breaking things early is intentional
blurb: Failure is a design tool.
fact: I believe that breaking things early, loudly, and intentionally is how you end up with systems that ship clean and remain stable.

title: Joy and discipline coexist in how I build
blurb: Playfulness does not replace rigor.
fact: The song captures the balance between the joy of building something yourself and the discipline of breaking systems intentionally to ensure they ship clean and stay that way.
